operating system: a software that manages computer hardware and software resources and provides common services for computer programs
asynchronous: not occurring at the same time; in computing, operations that can run independently without waiting for other operations to complete
synchronous: occurring at the same time; in computing, operations that must wait for other operations to complete before proceeding
dbms: Database Management System - software that manages and organizes data in databases
database: a structured collection of data that is stored and accessed electronically
api: Application Programming Interface - a set of protocols and tools for building software applications
cpu: Central Processing Unit - the main processor that executes instructions in a computer
gpu: Graphics Processing Unit - specialized processor designed for rendering graphics and parallel processing
ram: Random Access Memory - temporary storage that computers use to hold data and programs currently in use
sql: Structured Query Language - a programming language designed for managing data in relational databases
html: HyperText Markup Language - the standard markup language for creating web pages
css: Cascading Style Sheets - a language used for describing the presentation of web pages
javascript: a programming language commonly used for web development and creating interactive web pages
python: a high-level programming language known for its simplicity and readability
java: a popular object-oriented programming language used for building applications
algorithm: a step-by-step procedure for solving a problem or completing a task
artificial intelligence: the simulation of human intelligence in machines that are programmed to think and learn
machine learning: a type of artificial intelligence that enables computers to learn and improve from experience without being explicitly programmed
framework: a pre-written code structure that provides a foundation for developing applications
library: a collection of pre-written code that developers can use to perform common tasks
compiler: a program that translates source code written in a programming language into machine code
interpreter: a program that executes code line by line without compiling it first
variable: a storage location with an associated name that contains data
function: a block of code that performs a specific task and can be reused
loop: a programming construct that repeats a block of code multiple times
array: a data structure that stores multiple values in a single variable
object: a data structure that contains both data and methods to manipulate that data
class: a blueprint or template for creating objects in object-oriented programming
inheritance: a mechanism where a new class inherits properties and methods from an existing class
polymorphism: the ability of objects to take multiple forms and respond differently to the same method call
encapsulation: the bundling of data and methods that operate on that data within a single unit
recursion: a programming technique where a function calls itself to solve a problem
binary: a number system that uses only two digits: 0 and 1
bit: the smallest unit of data in computing, representing a single binary digit
byte: a unit of data consisting of 8 bits
network: a group of interconnected computers that can communicate and share resources
internet: a global network of interconnected computers that communicate using standardized protocols
server: a computer that provides services or resources to other computers over a network
client: a computer or program that requests services from a server
protocol: a set of rules that govern how data is transmitted over a network
encryption: the process of converting data into a coded format to prevent unauthorized access
firewall: a security system that monitors and controls network traffic
malware: malicious software designed to damage or gain unauthorized access to computer systems
virus: a type of malware that replicates itself and spreads to other files or systems
cloud computing: the delivery of computing services over the internet
backup: a copy of data stored separately to protect against data loss
cache: a temporary storage area that holds frequently accessed data for quick retrieval
url: Uniform Resource Locator - the address used to access resources on the internet
